awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology: Evolution of Drosophila wing spot: mechanisms of phenotypic divergence
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2022, Broadening Participation of Groups Underrepresented in Biology. The Fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow that will increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology. The Fellow aims to understand how animal pigmentation patterns are generated in nature—from the colored scales in butterfly wings to the stripes on the fur of mammals. This research in animal coloration will provide more information about the genes regulating pigmentation patterns. In this project, an insect, Drosophila, one of the most genetically tractable systems for understanding animal pigmentation, will be used to analyze how specific genes generate color patterns and how the genes themselves are controlled and organized into functional processes.  The broader impacts of this project include creating a Hispanic and Latino open online forum for Postdoctoral researchers and early Faculty across multiple Institutions in the Midwest. This will fill a gap by providing a supportive community for recruitment and retention to counter the “leaky pipeline” and enhance representation in STEM. 

This Project will use melanin patterns on fly wings from the genus Drosophila as a system for understanding how pigment patterns develop and evolve. Some of the better-understood genes involved in fly wing pigmentation include yellow (controls black melanin) and ebony (promotes a yellow pigment). Recently, genetic mapping has shown that the primary switch between the presence and absence of a male-specific wing spot in some fly species is not controlled by either of these genes but instead appears to be controlled by a gene called optomotor-blind (omb). Given that this transcription factor controls pigmentation in other parts of the fly body, the Fellow aims to elucidate when and where this gene is expressed in wings. The fellow will also determine whether omb is sufficient to guide the formation of the melanic spot or if other components are required. This project will support the scientific development of the Fellow by providing opportunities for developing new experimental skills in a genetic model system, which complements previous work in non-models, supporting the Fellow’s aspirations to become a Professor. The Fellow will also create online resources to promote professional development of other scientists from underrepresented groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Erick Bayala

Outcomes of Project:

 

The main overarching goal of this project is to investigate how animal pigmentation patterns are generated and modified in nature. I use Drosophila pigmentation as the key model system to address this overarching question due to its rich history as a model organism for both genetics and developmental biology. More specifically, I investigated the developmental basis of the formation of a male-specific wing spot in the specie Drosophila elegans. Such melanic spot is missing in females and its sister species Drosophila gunungcola making it an ideal candidate to elucidate when, where, and how such pigmentation element gets specified during fly development. Furthermore, and interestingly, the presence and evolution of such melanic spot don’t appear to be controlled by the common enzymes previously characterized as key regulators of fly pigmentation (Yellow, Ebony, Tan). Making the characterization of the genetic and developmental control of such melanic spot a good example of how new pigmentation patterns can arise and evolve in nature. The genetic switch controlling the presence or absence of this melanic spot has been mapped to a specific region containing a handful of genes. One of these genes is the transcription factor Optomotor-blind (Omb) which has been shown before to be a key regulator of multiple aspects of fly development. More importantly, this gene has been shown to control the early patterning process needed for proper abdominal pigmentation making it an ideal candidate for controlling the formation of this melanic spot. 

To investigate if Omb is responsible for the formation of such melanic spot and to ask similar questions across other pigmentation patterns and candidates I first developed techniques needed to analyze the expression of genes involved with the specification and evolution of such pigmentation patterns within Drosophila species across pupal stages. I was successful at adapting the Hybridization Chain Reaction technique to visualize the expression of multiple genes involved with pigmentation across different tissue types and during most of pupal development. Although the original intention was to apply this technique to see if Omb was responsible for the formation of the melanic spot, this technique by itself represented a substantial advancement in the way we study gene expression across fly pupal development. I wrote this technical advancement as a Method paper, which was published in the Journal Star Protocols from Cell Press (Bayala et al., 2024). When using this technique to analyze the expression of Omb across spotted and non-spotted flies, I was unable to observe differences. However, despite the lack of differences in Omb expression, I was able to still use the technique to provide an incredibly rich dataset for the expression of many genes involved with pigmentation across multiple tissues and species. Such other genes do exhibit interesting differences spatially and temporally which we can explore further in the future. This work is currently being prepared as a new manuscript providing details about all the developmental steps needed to organize and then produce a fly pigmentation pattern across multiple fly species. 

In terms of service, my work has focused on providing spaces for Latino researchers to communicate about their own experiences. This is with the objective of further enriching diversity within professional graduated and post-graduated spaces. One of the spaces where I have been able to leverage my background, experience with diversity work, and community has been within the Developing Future Biologist (DFB) program at the University of Michigan. This is a trainee-run organization (graduate students and postdocs) with the objective of first creating a training course for undergraduate students (from underrepresented and marginalized groups) interested in learning core concepts of research and developmental biology. Additionally, this organization maintains mentoring of students post-graduation guiding them into their future job aspirations. Finally, aligned with my prior ideas, DFB creates a sense of community among instructors by allowing them to develop important skills like course design, inclusive teaching, and program management. DFB was founded 10 years ago to provide research resources to students from Puerto Rico and still holds the majority participation by students from Puerto Rico which is the Latino community I hope to impact the most with my service work (due to my shared background). I have met constantly with postdoc and senior graduate students affiliated with the program, discussing relevant topics, designing rubrics, and developing the material needed for the course. Additionally, I have brought many of my contacts into the processes, aiding in collaboration and bridging opportunities for students across the entire U.S. And Puerto Rico. I have already taught in the program once during the summer of 2024 and will continue participating/teaching in it during 2025.

Erick Bayala, Pratyush Sinha, Patricia J. Wittkopp. (2024). Protocol for dissecting Drosophila pupae and visualizing RNA expression using hybridization chain reaction. STAR Protocols, 5(4), 103456. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.xpro.2024.103456
